Graphical abstract Fischer-Tropsch synthesis produces light olefins and long chain hydrocarbons from syngas generated from fossil and renewable feedstocks. Molybdenum carbide exhibits catalytic properties approaching those of metal catalysts in a number of hydrogenation reactions. The present paper focuses on the effect of promotion with potassium on the structure and performance of alumina supported carburized molybdenum catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Molybdenum carbide catalysts were synthesized by temperature programmed carburization in methane and hydrogen. Molybdenum was highly dispersed in both calcined and carburized alumina supported catalysts. Mixed oxides of potassium, molybdenum and aluminium were uncovered in the calcined promoted catalysts. These oxides are converted in molybdenum carbide species on their carburization. Potassium promotion strengthens interaction between molybdenum and aluminium. The potassium promoted catalysts exhibited higher selectivity to light olefins and long chain hydrocarbons but lower Fischer-Tropsch reaction rate compared to the unpromoted counterpart. The observed lower Fischer-Tropsch reaction rate on the promoted catalysts was attributed to more difficult carburization of the molybdenum species and electronic effects due to the presence of potassium. The light olefin and C5+ selectivities decrease at higher carbon monoxide conversion probably because of secondary olefin hydrogenation and hydrocarbon hydrogenolysis. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Molybdenum carbide Light olefins Promotion Potassium Selectivity 1 Introduction Depletion of crude oil resources has led to the growing interest in the alternative renewable and fossil feedstocks [1,2]. Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, which aims at converting syngas, has been regarded as one of most promising routes for renewable clean fuels and chemicals [3]. Syngas can be obtained by gasification of renewable or fossil sources such as biomass, organic waste or coal as well as from steam reforming/partial oxidation of natural or shale gas [4]. Light olefins (ethylene, propylene, and butylene) act as key building blocks for the petrochemical industry. Light olefins are manufactured in the industry either by naphtha steam cracking, ethane cracking or by the methanol to olefins process (MTO). In the naphtha steam cracking, olefins are by-side products and the selectivity to specific olefins is rather low. Ethane cracking produces only ethylene. The MTO technology involves a number of technological steps which reduce the overall conversion efficiency. In addition, the catalyst undergoes obvious deactivation. Thus, in comparison with traditional technologies, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis provides a new sustainable route for manufacturing light olefins. Molybdenum carbide (Mo2C) has electronic structure and catalytic performances in a number of catalytic reactions comparable to those of expensive noble metals (Pt and Ru). The molybdenum carbide phase has been widely used in hydrodesulfurization (HDS) and hydrodenitrogenation (HDN). It also exhibits high activity for dry reforming, alkane isomerization, methane dehydroaromatization and CO hydrogenation [5–9]. Molybdenum carbide has received growing attention during the past decades [10] as a catalyst for carbon monoxide hydrogenation. One of the major advantages of the molybdenum carbide catalyst is its resistance to carbon deposition compared to more conventional cobalt and iron Fischer-Tropsch catalysts [11,12]. Different to the molybdenum sulfide catalysts [13], no sulfur can be found in the reaction products over molybdenum carbide. Sulfur content can be a problem especially for production of fuels and chemicals with very strict sulfur specifications. Selectivity however remains a major challenge of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis over molybdenum carbide catalysts. The molybdenum carbide active phase mainly generates methane and light alkanes [14,15]. Addition of different promoters may lead to the modification of molybdenum structure, its electronic properties, reactivity of the active sites and reaction selectivity patterns. Previous reports [13–20] indicate that promotion of Mo2C-based catalysts with potassium and other alkali and transition metals significantly enhances their selectivity to alcohols in particular under high pressure. The potassium promoted molybdenum carbide catalysts also exhibit high activity in the water–gas shift (WGS) reaction. Many publications focus on the bulk molybdenum carbides [6,7,10,11,15–17,21–24], while very few reports have addressed so far supported molybdenum carbide catalysts [25,26]. Higher dispersion of the active phase, better chemical, mechanical and thermal stability are major advantages of supported catalysts. In addition, support can modify chemical and electronic structures of active sites and thus affect the catalytic performance of supported catalysts. The present paper focuses on the effect of promotion with K on the structure and catalytic performance of alumina supported molybdenum catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. At different preparation stages, the catalysts were characterized by nitrogen adsorption, X-ray fluorescence (XRF), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy, X-ray Photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) and Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM). The catalytic performance was evaluated in a fixed bed reactor as a function of K loading at different CO conversion levels. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The molybdenum catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of γ-alumina support (Puralox, Sasol, 50–150μm) with an aqueous solution of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Sigma-Aldrich). After being dried at 100°C overnight, the samples were calcined at 450°C under airflow for 6h. The calcined samples were mechanically milled with the K2CO3 precursor, and then recalcined at 450°C for 6h. The calcined catalysts are labelled as 10Mo-K(X)/Al2O3, where “10” represents the wt.% of molybdenum for all catalysts and X represents the K/Mo atomic ratio. The catalyst nomenclature, theoretical and measured elementary composition(in wt.%) are listed in Table 1 . The calcined catalysts were carburized with a mixture of H2/CH4 =4:1 for 2h at 700°C. For characterization, the carburized catalysts were passivated. A very small amount of O2 was introduced in the flowing N2 (1% O2 in N2) for passivation of the samples at room temperature. The carburized catalysts are labelled as 10Mo2C-K(X)/Al2O3, where X represents the atomic K/Mo ratio. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The catalysts were characterized using a combination of techniques. The BET surface area and average pore size distribution were measured using N2 adsorption-desorption at 77K. The isotherms were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 apparatus. The elementary composition of the samples was determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF). XRF analysis of the samples was measured using a Bruker M4 tornado spectrometer equipped with a Rhodium X-ray tube and X-Flash® SDD detector operating at 200μA current and 50KV voltage to obtain the samples spectra. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) was performed to determine the sample elemental composition. The X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded by a Siemens D5000 diffractometer using Cu (Kα) radiation at room temperature, 0.02° step size and 2s step time. The crystalline phases were identified by comparing the diffraction patterns with those of the standard powder XRD files (JCPDS) published by the International Center for Diffraction Data. The hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was carried out on AutoChem II 2920 apparatus (Micromeritics) using 0.05g of the sample under 5vol.% H2/Ar stream (50cm3/min). The temperature was increased from room temperature to 750°C at a rate of 10°C/min. The catalyst basicity was measured by carbon dioxide temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD). The samples were pretreated under a flow of helium at 150°C for 2h to remove the adsorbed water, and then were exposed to CO2 at 130°C during 1h. The CO2 desorption was measured while heating the catalysts with the pre-adsorbed carbon dioxide up to 700°C with a temperature ramp of 15°C/min under a flow of He. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements were performed using a TECNAI microscope operating at a voltage of 200kV. The catalyst powder was ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol and deposited on a copper grid prior to the measurements. The Raman spectra of the calcined Mo-based catalysts were recorded using a Dilor XY800 spectrometer with a Krypton ion laser (Spectra Physics model Beamlok). A laser wavelength of 532nm and a filter with diameter of 0.6 were employed. The dispersed radiation was measured by the CCD (Charge Coupled Device) detector cooled with liquid nitrogen. The data acquisition and processing were performed using the LabSpec software. The X-ray Photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were recorded with a VG ESCALAB 220 XL spectrometer equipped with a monochromatic Al Kα (E=1486.6eV) X-ray source. The binding energies (BE) of Mo 3d and C 1s were determined by computer fitting of the measured spectra and referred to the Al 2p peak of the support at 74.6eV, using Casa XPS software. The binding energies were estimated within ±0.2eV. 2.3 Catalytic tests Carbon monoxide hydrogenation reaction was performed in a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor (8mm inner diameter). Prior to the catalytic tests, 0.3g of calcined molybdenum catalysts were carburized in situ with a mixture of H2/CH4 =4:1 for 2h at 700°C, then the reactor was cooled down to 100°C under N2 flow. A syngas with a molar ratio of H2/CO=2 was switched through the reactor and the total pressure was increased to 10bar. Subsequently, the temperature was increased up to 300°C. The temperature ramp was of 5°C/min from 100°C to 200°C, then of 0.5°C/min from 200°C to 300°C. The reaction was conducted at least during 40h to reach the stable catalytic performance. The gaseous products were analyzed by on-line gas chromatography. Analysis of N2, CO, CO2, and CH4 was performed using a packed CTR-1 column and a TCD detector. Gaseous hydrocarbons (C1–C4) and alcohols were separated in a capillary Rt-Q PLOT column and analyzed by a FID detector. The liquid products (oil and water phases) were collected in the trap kept at 20°C and analyzed off-line by gas chromatography. The selectivity of each product was calculated on carbon basis. Light olefins production rate was evaluated from space time yields (STY): moles of CO converted to light olefins per gram of catalyst per second (molCO gcat −1 s−1). 3 Results 3.1 Characterization of catalyst structure The textural properties of the alumina support, calcined and carburized Mo-based catalysts are displayed in Table 2 . The surface area and pore volume slightly decrease after impregnation of the alumina with molybdenum, while the pore diameter is almost unaffected. This decrease is probably partially due to both the effect of “dilution” of the support with molybdenum and possibly the partial blockage of the alumina pores by molybdenum species. In addition, the potassium promotion resulted in a further slight decrease in the catalyst surface area. The BET surface area also decreased after carburization (123m2/g before and 120m2/g after carburization for 10Mo/Al2O3 catalyst). The normalized Raman spectra of the oxidized 10Mo-K(X)/Al2O3 catalysts are reported in Fig. 1 . The spectra exhibit the presence of MoO3, Al2(MoO4)3 and polymolybdates species. The presence of MoO3 in 10Mo/Al2O3 and in all the 10Mo-K(X)/Al2O3 catalysts is evidenced by the characteristic peaks of MoO3 with the Raman frequencies of 288, 335, 664, 818 and 995cm−1 [26–30]. The Raman spectra also exhibit a small band at 377 cm−1 that could correspond to the Al2(MoO4)3 species resulting from the interaction of molybdenum with the alumina support [31,32]. However, the intensity of this band is low, indicating a weak interaction between Mo and Al or a high dispersion of Mo on the alumina surface. After potassium promotion, the spectra of calcined 10Mo-K(X)/Al2O3 catalysts revealed a dominant asymmetric feature at 951cm−1 and a small band at 349cm−1, which can be assigned to symmetric stretching of the Mo=O bond in octahedrally coordinated Mo6+ species such as Mo4O6 2− and Mo7O24 2− [26,33]. These two molybdenum species can be assigned to the K-Mo mixed phases as the relative intensity of these peaks increases obviously along with the potassium amount. The Raman data suggest that potassium promotion results in a stronger interaction between molybdenum and potassium, thus leading to the formation of mixed K-Mo and/or K-Mo-Al oxides phases. The X-ray diffraction patterns for the unpromoted and potassium-promoted Mo2C/Al2O3, MoO3/Al2O3 catalysts and unsupported Mo2C are shown in Fig. 2 . The broadening of the characteristics XRD peaks of the orthorhombic MoO3 phase (at 2θ=23.3° and 27.3°) indicates high dispersion of molybdenum species on the alumina support [34]. After the carburization, no characteristic peaks of MoO2 or MoO3 were detected in the XRD patterns of the unpromoted and promoted Mo2C/Al2O3 catalysts indicating successful molybdenum oxide conversion into the oxycarbide and/or carbides phases. Note, however, that some of the β-Mo2C XRD peaks may overlap with the characteristic peaks of alumina. This could be a reason why Mo2C is not easily identified by XRD in the alumina supported catalysts. Note however that even the β-Mo2C characteristic peaks at 2θ=52.3°, 61.9° and 75.0° which are clearly distinguishable from XRD patterns of Al2O3 were not detected in the carburized catalysts. This could be indicative of very high dispersion of supported molybdenum carbide on alumina, its crystallite sizes should be below the detection limits of X-ray diffraction [35]. Interestingly, no new diffraction peaks are observed in the potassium promoted catalysts corresponding to K-containing crystalline phases. However, the Raman spectra imply the existence of K-Mo and K-Mo-Al mixed phase after K promotion. The K-containing phases could be located in small crystalline particles, which sizes are below the detection limits of X-ray diffraction. Fig. 3 shows the bright field TEM images of 10Mo2C/Al2O3 and 10Mo2C-K(1/5)/Al2O3 catalysts. They shows the presence of highly dispersed molybdenum on the Al2O3 surface. The average particle size of molybdenum carbide is ∼1nm, which is consistent with previous reports by Shou et al. [36] or by Stellwagen et al. [37]. Very small sizes of molybdenum carbide nanoparticles can explain the absence of X-ray diffraction peaks of the Mo carbide phases. The Mo 3d XPS spectra of the carburized 10Mo2C/Al2O3 and 10Mo2C-K(1/5)/Al2O3 catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 4 A and C. XPS fit parameters using same FWHMs of corresponding components of the Mo 3d spectra are listed in Table S1 in Supplementary Material. The broad envelop of the Mo 3d signal can be decomposed into three separate overlapping doublets indicating the presence of Mo species in several oxidation states. When doped with potassium in a ratio K/Mo=1/5, the position of the Mo 3d5/2 peaks remained unchanged. Interestingly, no characteristic peak of metallic molybdenum was detected. According to the literature [12,24,38,39], the peak at binding energy (BE) of 228.6eV can be attributed to the Mo species in the Mo carbide phase. It has been denoted as Moδ+ (with 0<δ<4) and is assumed to be involved in a Mo–C bond. The peak at 229.9eV can be attributed to the Mo4+ species and the peak at 232.9eV can be assigned to the Mo6+ species [40,41]. The presence of those two later species can be explained by molybdenum oxidation during the passivation step. The carbon C 1s signal was also decomposed (Fig. 4B and D). Relevant XPS fit parameters corresponding to the C 1s component are listed in Table S2 in Supplementary Material. Four components were found. The signal at binding energy of 284.8eV was attributed to adventitious carbon. It can be also associated to CC bond from amorphous carbon or graphitic-like carbon which are deposited on the catalyst surface during the carburization as reported by several authors [42–45]. The peak at binding energy of 286.1eV and 288.8eV was attributed to CO and CO, respectively [46], remaining from the passivating treatment. The signal at 282.9eV was attributed to carbon atoms in the carbide phase. Thus, XPS confirms the presence of molybdenum carbide species. The surface composition of the catalysts and fractions of different Mox species measured by XPS are shown in Table 3 . Compared to 10Mo2C/Al2O3 catalyst, an evident decrease in the percentage for Mo corresponding to Mo carbide phase over 10Mo2C-K(1/5)/Al2O3 catalyst was observed, which implies that potassium promotion may inhibit carburization of the molybdenum species. Note that the K/Mo ratio on the surface of the carburized 10Mo2C-K(1/5)/Al2O3 catalyst is close to the theoretical value (13.7wt.% of Mo and 0.9wt.% of K). The simple close-packed monolayer model (capacity of 0.12g MoO3/100m2 [47,48]), suggests the presence of molybdenum monolayer on alumina. Hence, Mo is highly dispersed on the alumina surface. This is also consistent with the TEM measurements. The presence of potassium seems to slightly decrease the dispersion of molybdenum (Mo/Al=0.44 and 0.32 for 10Mo2C/Al2O3 and 10Mo2C-K(1/5)/Al2O3, respectively). Moreover, the molybdenum particles could be covered by potassium during the mechanical mixing. Note that the amount of potassium on the catalyst surface corresponds to the overall loading amount (around 0.9wt.%). There is a larger fraction of oxygen at the surface (O/Mo=2.45 and 3.08 for 10Mo2C/Al2O3 and 10Mo2C-K(1/5)/Al2O3, respectively). Hence, the passivation treatment leads to the partial and/or total oxidation of some outer surface molybdenum species. The basicity of the Al2O3 support and molybdenum carbide catalysts was measured by CO2-TPD. The results are shown in Fig. 5 . All the samples showed broad CO2 desorption profiles from 150–700°C, which can be decomposed into 3 peaks after fitting with Gauss functions. The peaks located in the temperature range of 150–350°C are assigned to weak basic sites; the peaks between 200–550°C are assigned to moderate basic sites; the peaks in the range of 400–700°C were attributed to strong basic sites. The alumina support possesses mainly moderate basic sites. The presence of molybdenum leads to a slight shift of the CO2-TPD peaks to the lower temperature. This shift is more noticeable with the increase in K content. Not surprisingly, with the addition of potassium, the quantity of weak, moderate and strong basic sites increases. The amount of CO2 adsorption measured from the CO2-TPD is reported in Table 4 . The amount of total CO2 desorption confirms that the addition of potassium contributes to higher concentration of basic sites.This result is in agreement with the Raman data showing that the addition of potassium contributes to the strong interaction between Mo and K. In comparison to the non-promoted Mo2C/Al2O3 catalyst, the concentrations of weak (150–350°C) and moderate (200–550°C) basic sites significantly increase with the addition of potassium. Interestingly, the concentration of the strong basic sites did not change much with the increase in the K content. The H2-TPR curves of 10Mo2C/Al2O3 and 10Mo2C-K(X)/Al2O3 catalysts with X=1/5 and 1/1 are shown in Fig. 6 . The TPR displays an intense hydrogen consumption peak between 250–450°C and a smaller hydrogen consumption peak between 475–600°C. Previous reports suggest [42–45] that several layers of carbon can be formed on the surface of an ideal Mo2C phase during the carburization depending of the carbon source and carburization temperature. Note that some molybdenum species can be oxidized during the passivation. The hydrogen consumption of the first peak can be therefore attributed to the reduction of oxidized molybdenum species. The second peak can be attributed to the hydrogenation of carbidic carbon and/or hydrogenolysis of polymeric carbon. Note however that the bulk Mo2C phase is stable in the presence of hydrogen. Lee [42] and Leclercq [44] showed that the Mo2C structure can be maintained even after exposure to hydrogen at 700°C for 10h. The TPR profiles of 10Mo2C/Al2O3 and 10Mo2C-K(1/5)/Al2O3 are similar. Interestingly, the first reduction peak slightly shifts to higher temperature with the increase in K content. This behavior may be due to the change in the interaction between active Mo components and support, and the presence of mixed K-Mo phases. The potassium promotion influences both the position of the TPR peaks and H2 consumptions measured from the TPR profiles (Table 5 ). The hydrogen consumption is almost 50% smaller with the 10Mo2C-K(1/1)/Al2O3 catalyst compared to the 10Mo2C/Al2O3 counterpart. Molybdenum reducibility seems to be hindered by the presence of potassium. This may be due to the formation of mixed K-Mo phases seen by Raman spectroscopy, but also to the Mo2C surface covered, at least partially, by potassium. 3.2 Catalytic data Carbon monoxide hydrogenation was conducted at 300°C under a total pressure of 10bar and with the H2/CO ratio of 2. The catalytic results obtained with unpromoted and potassium promoted molybdenum catalysts are given in Table 6 . Both unpromoted and potassium promoted molybdenum carbide catalysts were relatively stable; the catalytic performance remained unchanged during at least 40h. The CO conversion and product selectivities were obtained at the steady state conditions. GHSV varied from 4000 to 12000cm3 g−1 h−1. Methane, light olefins and paraffins, alcohols, heavy hydrocarbons and carbon dioxide were the major reaction products. For the sake of clarity, carbon dioxide was included in the total selectivity calculations, but is excluded from the hydrocarbon and alcohol selectivities. In agreement with previous reports [49–51], addition of potassium significantly influences the catalytic performance of the 10Mo2C/Al2O3 catalyst. The CO conversion at GHSV=12 000cm3 g−1 h−1 decreased from 14.4% to less than 0.2% with the increase in K/Mo ratio. Similarly, a decrease in the CH4, CO2, light paraffin and alcohol selectivities was observed. At the same time, an increase in light olefin selectivity (from 9% to 17.3%) and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivity (from 6.9% to 36.3%) was observed under these conditions. Note that the light olefin space time yields (STY) decrease with K promotion. The same trends were observed when comparing the catalytic performances at different GHSV. The decrease in GHSV led to an increase in the CO conversion over the same catalyst (from 5.2% at 12000cm3 g−1 h−1 up to 23.5% at 4000cm3 g−1 h−1 for the 10Mo2C-K(1/2)/Al2O3 catalyst and from less than 0.2% at 12000cm3 g−1 h−1 up to 8.2% at 4000cm3 g−1 h−1 for the 10Mo2C-K(1/1)/Al2O3 catalyst). The selectivity to different products is also affected by the conversion. At high CO conversion, the methane, light paraffin and CO2 selectivities increased at the expense of the olefin and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivities. Interestingly, the light olefin STY is only slightly affected by GHSV and carbon monoxide conversion. The increase in carbon monoxide conversion at lower GHSV is compensated by lower light olefin selectivity. The resulting olefin productivity remains almost the same for a given catalyst. The observed relatively low alcohol selectivities on the molybdenum carbide based catalysts can be explained by the reaction pressure. Commonly higher alcohol selectivity is obtained under high pressure reaction conditions (P>30bar). At similar conversion value (5.4% at 12000cm3 g−1 h−1 for 10Mo2C-K(1/2)/Al2O3 and 4.2% at 6000cm3 g−1 h−1 for 10Mo2C-K(1/1)/Al2O3), higher light olefins and C5 + selectivities along with lower methane and light paraffin selectivities were obtained with the catalysts containing a higher amount of potassium. As reported in the literature [50], high potassium content is favorable for synthesis of light olefins and heavy hydrocarbons. Fig. 7 (a and b) presents the relations between the product selectivities and carbon monoxide conversion for all studied catalysts. The selectivities to light olefins (C2=) and C5+ hydrocarbons decrease with an increase in CO conversion, while light paraffins (C2), methane and carbon dioxide selectivities increase. Lower selectivity to light olefins at higher conversion can be due to their secondary hydrogenation, while higher CH4 selectivity at high CO conversion can be probably due to hydrogenolysis of higher hydrocarbons. The increase in CO2 selectivity (Fig. 7a) can be assigned to the WGS reaction (CO+H2O⇆CO2 + H2). H2/CO ratio also significantly affects the product selectivity. Table 7 presents the steady-state activity and selectivity in the CO hydrogenation on the 10Mo2C-K(1/2)/Al2O3 catalyst and 10Mo2C-K(1/1)/Al2O3 catalyst at 300°C, 10bar, and H2/CO ratio of 1 and 2. Once the H2/CO ratio decreased from 2 to 1, the CO conversion decreased from 20.1% to 11.4% for the 10Mo2C-K(1/2)/Al2O3 catalyst and from 15.1% to 9.6% for the 10Mo2C-K(1/1)/Al2O3 catalyst. The light olefin and C5+ selectivities increase, while methane, light paraffin and alcohol selectivities decrease. Interestingly, the selectivity to CO2 also decreases at lower H2/CO ratio. The light olefin STYs decrease with a decrease in H2/CO ratio for these two catalysts. At similar CO conversion (around 10.5%) for the different K promoted catalysts at different H2/CO ratios (10,7% for the catalyst with K/Mo=1/5 (Table 6); 11.4% for the catalyst with K/Mo=1/2; 9.6% for the catalyst with K/Mo=1/1 at H2/CO=1 (Table 7)), the light olefin, alcohol and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivities increase with the increase in the potassium content and with the decrease in the H2/CO ratio. Correspondingly, at similar CO conversion, methane and light paraffin selectivities are lower when a potassium amount is higher and the H2/CO ratio is lower. In agreement with previous reports [52], lower H2/CO ratio seems to be favorable for the production of light olefins and higher hydrocarbons. 4 Discussion Let us first discuss the effect of promotion with potassium on the structure of molybdenum carbide species supported on alumina. The nitrogen adsorption suggests that promotion with potassium does not significantly modify the catalyst textural properties. The surface area and pore volume slightly decrease with potassium addition, while the catalyst pore diameter is not much affected by potassium addition. The effect of promotion with potassium on the catalyst texture is attributed to partial plugging of alumina pores and effect of support dilution. XPS indicates formation of molybdenum carbide after temperature-programmed carburization using the CH4/H2 mixture while potassium slightly inhibits carburization of the molybdenum species. TEM images indicate that molybdenum carbide particles are highly dispersed on the alumina support. The TEM results are also consistent with the XRD patterns and suggesting higher molybdenum dispersion. No obvious peaks characteristic of Mo oxide have been detected by XRD in the carburized catalysts. This suggests that molybdenum dispersion remains relatively high after the carburization. The molybdenum phase composition is strongly affected by addition of potassium in both calcined and carburized catalysts. There are obvious interactions between K and Mo species and between those species and alumina support. Higher potassium content further enhances interaction of molybdenum phase with alumina support and results in mixed K-Mo, Mo-Al and K-Mo-Al oxides identified by Raman spectroscopy and confirmed by H2-TPR (the decrease in hydrogen consumption with the increase in potassium). The addition of potassium leads to the increase in the concentration of weak and moderate basic sites of the catalyst. Similar phenomena are previously observed with supported molybdenum sulfide catalysts [49]. Addition of potassium affects the catalyst structure in several ways. First, during the mechanical mixing, potassium covers the Mo particles. Second, interaction of molybdenum and potassium results in formation of mixed molybdenum potassium compounds: potassium molybdates in the calcined catalyst which can then be converted into mixed potassium-molybdenum carbides. The catalytic data suggest that the carbon monoxide conversion over the unpromoted molybdenum carbide catalyst mainly generates methane, light paraffins and carbon dioxide. In agreement with previous reports [14,23], it can be concluded that the unpromoted molybdenum carbide active sites do not produce olefins, alcohols and C5+ hydrocarbons. Catalyst promotion with potassium results in lower FT reaction rate most probably due to lower extent of molybdenum carburization and possible electronic effect of potassium on molybdenum carbide. At the same time, the selectivities to light olefins and C5+ hydrocarbons significantly increase. Several phenomena can be responsible for higher selectivity to light olefins and long chain hydrocarbons. First, addition of potassium can possibly block the most active catalyst hydrogenation sites. Similar effects were previously observed for iron catalysts where the promotion with alkali ions led to higher olefins and C5+ hydrocarbons selectivities [52–55]. The promoted catalysts exhibited the presence of the mixed phases of potassium and molybdenum carbide. The presence of potassium in the mixed phase can modify electronic structure of molybdenum carbide and affect the rate of FT reaction elementary steps, for example, carbon monoxide dissociation. In addition, the catalyst basicity is another parameter that affects the product selectivity of Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. The increase in catalyst basicity would restraint secondary reactions such as hydrogenation of olefins or hydrogenolysis of higher hydrocarbons [50,53]. This would result in higher olefins and heavy hydrocarbons selectivity along with lower CH4 selectivity. Fig. 7 displays the C2 olefin, C2 paraffin, CO2, methane and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivities plotted versus carbon monoxide conversion for the studied potassium promoted molybdenum catalysts. Some general correlations can be observed though the data show some scattering due the effect of potassium promotion on the reaction selectivities. Interestingly, the selectivity to light olefins and long chain hydrocarbons decreases with an increase in carbon monoxide conversion, while the methane selectivity and selectivity to the C2 C4 paraffins increase. As a result, the light olefin space time yield is only slightly influenced by the CO conversion (Table 6). This suggests that the olefin selectivity is possibly limited by secondary hydrogenation and hydrocarbon hydrogenolysis under the studied conditions. This can possibly explain that lowering catalyst hydrogenation activity by promotion with potassium on the one hand, and lowering H2/CO ratio in the syngas on the other hand, can improve to some extent the olefin and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivities. 5 Conclusion Promotion of alumina supported carburized molybdenum catalysts with potassium results in modification of both their structure and catalytic performance in FT synthesis. Addition of potassium enhances the interaction between molybdenum and alumina support. A noticeable increase in the concentration of weak and moderate basic sites was observed in the potassium promoted catalysts. The unpromoted molybdenum carbide catalyst mainly generates methane, carbon dioxide and light alkanes. The addition of potassium promoter results in a decrease in the FT reaction rate most probably because of the formation of more difficultly carburized potassium-molybdenum and molybdenum-aluminium mixed oxides and electronic effects due to the promoter. Potassium promotion leads however to higher light olefin and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivities. Higher light olefin and C5+ hydrocarbon selectivities can be possibly attributed to the lower hydrogenation activity of the promoted catalysts. The decrease in the selectivity to light olefins and C5+ hydrocarbons at higher carbon monoxide conversions was attributed to secondary hydrogenation and hydrocarbon hydrogenolysis leading to light paraffins and methane. coredata.dc:description: Fischer-Tropsch synthesis produces light olefins and long chain hydrocarbons from syngas generated from fossil and renewable feedstocks. Molybdenum carbide exhibits catalytic properties approaching those of metal catalysts in a number of hydrogenation reactions. The present paper focuses on the effect of promotion with potassium on the structure and performance of alumina supported carburized molybdenum catalysts in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis. Molybdenum carbide catalysts were synthesized by temperature programmed carburization in methane and hydrogen. Molybdenum was highly dispersed in both calcined and carburized alumina supported catalysts. Mixed oxides of potassium, molybdenum and aluminium were uncovered in the calcined promoted catalysts. These oxides are converted in molybdenum carbide species on their carburization. Potassium promotion strengthens interaction between molybdenum and aluminium. The potassium promoted catalysts exhibited higher selectivity to light olefins and long chain hydrocarbons but lower Fischer-Tropsch reaction rate compared to the unpromoted counterpart. The observed lower Fischer-Tropsch reaction rate on the promoted catalysts was attributed to more difficult carburization of the molybdenum species and electronic effects due to the presence of potassium. The light olefin and C5+ selectivities decrease at higher carbon monoxide conversion probably because of secondary olefin hydrogenation and hydrocarbon hydrogenolysis.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of potassium promotion on the structure and performance of alumina supported carburized molybdenum catalysts for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis
